title: 103_hr429
content: The "Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act" designates amounts for the reduction of public debt under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It introduces a new part for the designation of funds towards reducing public debt. The "Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act" allows individuals to designate up to 10% of their income tax liability to reduce public debt. This designation must be made when filing tax returns and is subtracted from the income tax liability. The "Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act" allows individuals to designate up to 10% of their income tax liability to reduce public debt. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the date of the enactment of this Act. A new section titled "PUBLIC DEBT REDUCTION TRUST FUND" is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States to pay off federal government obligations included in the public debt. Amounts designated for public debt reduction are appropriated to the Trust Fund, and any obligations paid with Trust Fund amounts are canceled and retired. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is used to pay off federal government obligations, and any obligations paid with Trust Fund amounts are canceled and retired. The table of sections for the subchapter is amended to reflect this. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established to pay off federal government obligations, with any amounts received after the enactment of the Act subject to the amendments made. Additionally, a new section is added for taxpayer-generated sequestration of federal spending to reduce the public debt. Sequestration procedures are mandated within 15 days after Congress adjourns, following any prior sequestration requirements. The Department of the Treasury estimates the aggregate amount designated under the Internal Revenue Code for the last taxable year, adjusted for discretionary spending reductions and deficit changes. The sequestration procedures for fiscal year 1996 and beyond are based on enacted appropriations from fiscal year 1995 and the deficit change from direct spending legislation. Accounts of the United States will be reduced by a uniform percentage to achieve these reductions, with certain accounts exempted from benefit reductions under the Social Security Act. The sequestration procedures for fiscal year 1996 and beyond are based on enacted appropriations from fiscal year 1995 and the deficit change from direct spending legislation. Accounts of the United States will be reduced by a uniform percentage to achieve these reductions, with certain accounts exempted from benefit reductions under the Social Security Act, including specific funds such as the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the National Credit Union Administration. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include reports on sequestration to reduce the public debt. The Department of Treasury is required to report to Congress estimating the amount of income tax designated under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include reports on sequestration to reduce the public debt. The Department of Treasury must report to Congress estimates for the budget year, including the aggregate amount designated under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, required reductions under section 253A, and the sequestration percentage needed to achieve the reduction. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include sequestration reports to reduce public debt. The expiration date in section 275(b) does not apply to these amendments, which will end when there is no public debt in a fiscal year.
